full_text: An activity represents a task that someone must attend to or an issue that someone should be aware of. Log in as any user, for example, Alice Applegate. The activities assigned to a user are displayed on the user's desktop page and they can be filtered. Clicking on an activity opens the activity worksheet and it automatically opens the entity it is related to. In this case, the Premium Report. The user can take actions on the activity, such as Complete, Reassign, and Add a Note, etc. Click OK or Cancel to click on the activity. Close the worksheet if you do not want to complete it yet. The activities related to a job are all displayed on the work plan page in the Tools section. The user can create a new activity on the job by clicking Actions, New Activity. There are sets of predefined categories of activity patterns to use. For example, an auditor can create an activity for the underwriter to review the Premium Report. Click OK to create the activity. Go to the policy. Go to the policy. Go to the policy file. The activities related to a policy are all displayed on the policy summary page and include those from the associated policy transactions. The user can create a new activity on the policy by clicking Actions, New Activity. This time, create an activity to meet with the insured on the policy. An activity bubbles up from policy job to policy and to account. The activity bubbles up from policy job to policy and to account. The activity is related to an account. The activities related to an account are all displayed on the account summary page and include those from the associated policies and policy transactions. Similarly, the user can create a new activity on the account by clicking Actions, New Activity. Create an activity to get inspection for loss control and assign it to inspector. An activity bubbles up from policy job to policy and to account. It is always related to an account by default. This is the end of demonstration of activity-based.

segments.text: An activity represents a task that someone must attend to or an issue that someone should be aware of. Log in as any user, for example, Alice Applegate. The activities assigned to a user are displayed on the user's desktop page and they can be filtered. Clicking on an activity opens the activity worksheet and it automatically opens the entity it is related to. In this case, the Premium Report. The user can take actions on the activity, such as Complete, Reassign, and Add a Note, etc. Click OK or Cancel to click on the activity.
Close the worksheet if you do not want to complete it yet.

The activities related to a job are all displayed on the work plan page in the Tools section. The user can create a new activity on the job by clicking Actions, New Activity. There are sets of predefined categories of activity patterns to use. For example, an auditor can create an activity for the underwriter to review the Premium Report. Click OK to create the activity.
Go to the policy. Go to the policy. Go to the policy file.

The activities related to a policy are all displayed on the policy summary page and include those from the associated policy transactions. The user can create a new activity on the policy by clicking Actions, New Activity. This time, create an activity to meet with the insured on the policy.
An activity bubbles up from policy job to policy and to account.
The activity bubbles up from policy job to policy and to account.
The activity is related to an account.
The activities related to an account are all displayed on the account summary page and include those from the associated policies and policy transactions.
Similarly, the user can create a new activity on the account by clicking Actions, New Activity.
Create an activity to get inspection for loss control and assign it to inspector.
An activity bubbles up from policy job to policy and to account.
It is always related to an account by default.
This is the end of demonstration of activity-based.
